title: Serpiginous Choroiditis: Clinical Overview and Pathophysiology
short_description: Clinical document describing serpiginous choroiditis, a rare recurrent eye disorder characterized by irregularly shaped lesions affecting the retinal pigment epithelium and choriocapillaris.
long_description: This clinical reference document provides a comprehensive overview of serpiginous choroiditis, one of the white dot syndromes involving inflammation of the retina and choroid. The document details the characteristic irregularly shaped lesions that affect two layers of the eye surface, clinical presentation including painless vision loss and visual field defects, and the typical bilateral involvement pattern. It discusses the unknown etiology while exploring potential causes including abnormal immune responses, localized vasculitis, impaired blood circulation, and possible chemical exposure. The document also covers demographic patterns, noting the condition's rarity, male predominance, and typical onset during early to middle adult years.
